string_table.string: Skip Navigation. Hit enter to return to the slide.

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript: Hello everyone! Welcome to the lecture on qualitative research methods. This lecture is designed by Dr. Candace Chou and narrated by Dr. Karen Kozen-Lien.

By the end of the lecture, you will understand:

• Nature and characteristics of qualitative research

• Qualitative research validity

• Six main approaches

• Qualitative data collection methods, including

• Interviewing

• Observation

• Document analysis

Qualitative Research is no less scientific than quantitative studies.

It uses systematic and rigorous approaches.

Characterized by multiple realities.

Researcher’s biases must be understood and included in interpreting findings.

Six main approaches

• Ethnographic studies

• Case studies

• Phenomenological studies

• Grounded theory

• Critical studies

• Narrative inquiry

We will discuss each method in the next few slides.

First, let’s take a look at the key characteristics of qualitative research:

• It’s usually conducted at a natural setting to observe behavior that occurs naturally.

• The data is collected directly from participants.

• It provides rich narrative descriptions to provide in-depth understanding.

• It’s process-oriented by focusing on how and why behaviors occur. It allows for conclusions that explain reasons for the results.

• It uses inductive data analysis from synthesized information to provide generalizations. Conclusions are developed from the “ground up”. We will discuss the specific steps in the next slide.

• It emphasizes participant perspectives by focusing is on participants’ understanding and meaning.

• It’s socially constructed meaning from Knowledge that is based on experience and social interactions.

• The research design evolves and changes so it’s considered emergent research design. Qualitative researchers enter the investigation with some ideas about what data will be collected but a full picture of the methods is given retrospectively; after all the data have been collected. The design is emergent in that it remains flexible and evolves during the study.

Qualitative researchers do not formulate hypotheses and gather data to prove or disprove them (that is a deductive process). Rather, the data are gathered first and then synthesized inductively to generate generalizations, models, or frameworks. There are six basic steps.

Step 1 Gather extensive detailed data

Step 2 Read text or notes closely

Step 3 Code and verify data

Step 4 Create categories from code

Step 5 Reduce categories to eliminate redundancy

Step 6 Compose conclusion, model framework

In the beginning, the data may seem unconnected and too extensive to make much sense, but as the researcher works with the data, progressively more specific findings and deeper understanding and connections are generated.

Validity refers to the degree of truthfulness or trustworthiness in a study. We often ask, “do the data and conclusions accurately, fairly, plausibly, and authentically portray reality?”

A term “credibility” is often used in qualitative research. Credibility refers to whether the results portray the views of the participants. The goal is to sample, collect data, and analyze data to minimize the threats to validity.

There are many possible threats to the validity of a qualitative research that we must address.

o Context insensitivity

• When the researcher does not give enough attention to the context, e.g., time periods, cultural mores, laws, other adults present, playgrounds…

• Researchers need to provide sufficient, detailed descriptions (thick descriptions).

o Inadequate participant perspectives

• When too much attention is given to the researcher’s interpretations.

• Participant perspectives need to be rich, detailed, and abundant.

o Researcher bias

• Because qualitative studies are exploratory, open-ended, and flexible, researcher bias is a constant concern.

• Bias must be addressed by recognizing it and examining it through critical self-reflection of the researcher.

o Inadequate transparency

• When there is unclear, missing, or scant explanations about the whys and hows of the study, as well as the interpretations

• Researcher must provide explicit, clear, and complete information about all aspects of the study.

o Inauthenticity

• Cherry-picking the views that support the researcher’s viewpoint

• The results need to be genuine, real, accurate, and complete, in original voices and other data.

o Instrumentation

• This refers to the nature of data collection and the procedures to gather information, including the person who collects the data. This happens due to

o Lack of interviewer or observer training

o No pilot interview

o Asking different questions

o Only using one observer

o Confirmability

• The researcher needs to show original data and audit trails so others can understand the process and decision-making.

• It’s a threat to validity if there is no way to check or corroborate what the researcher did.

o Sampling

• Because qualitative studies depend heavily on a few individuals or sites, the nature of the sample is critical.

• Researchers need to provide clear descriptions of their samples and how they were selected.

• Researchers should consider the participants’ characteristics when drawing conclusions.

Now let’s review the six main qualitative research methods.

First, ethnographic studies or ethnography.

• The goal is to take a holistic, emergent learning approach to better understand the sociocultural contexts within bounded cultural systems.

• It involves fieldwork—interacting with members of the culture exploring all aspects

• The focus is on shared patterns of beliefs and norms.

There are six steps to conduct an ethnographic study.

Step 1: Identify the purpose consistent with ethnographic approach

Step 2: Identify culture-sharing group and settings

Step 3: Select purposeful sampling procedures and entry to the field

Step 4: Schedule fieldwork and determine data collection methods

Step 5: Collect data, analyze, and determine additional data collection

Step 6: Analyze data for themes

Step 7: Interpret themes, relationships, and other findings that lead to conclusions

Although there can be some variations, these are the typically steps to conduct an ethnographic study.

Case studies

Case studies use In-depth analysis of one or more real-life “entities”—events, settings, programs, social groups, communities, individuals, or other “bounded” systems.

Examples of single cases include a classroom, school, a bullying prevention program, an academic department at the university or an event, such as the introduction of laptop computers for students. The case Is used as an illustration of a phenomenon that can be described, explored, and understood.

A single entity could be an investigation of a program in one school, which would be a within-site or intrinsic single-case study. If the program is studied in a number of different schools, it would be a multisite, multiple, or collective case study. The goal is to learn about the system through a holistic approach involving detailed description.

Case study has been identified as a qualitative research method because in-depth studies of a single entity use qualitative methods to gather data. Oftentimes, both quantitative and qualitative data are collected. Here we will focus on the qualitative aspect of a case study.

Although case studies are great for providing detailed, thorough, and deep understanding of a case, the criticism of case studies include weak generalizability and time consuming. It takes a long time to collect all types of data and it might be hard to replicate the study in other settings.

Phenomenological studies or phenomenology

• The purpose is to describe, clarify, and interpret the everyday life experiences (or lived experiences) of participants to understand the “essence” of the experience as consciously perceived and described by the participants.

• The basis of phenomenology is that what and how something is experienced by several individuals provide data that can lead to a deep understanding of common meaning..

• The focus is on finding commonalities.

• e.g., Grief experienced by students upon the death of a classmate or beginning teachers’ experiences with mentors.

Grounded theory studies

A grounded theory study is characterized by a unique purpose -- to discover or generate theory from real-world data that explain central phenomena. The intent is to focus on theory generation, rather than theory confirmation. By gathering view of participants and applying systematic data analysis, the theory emerges. In this sense, the theory is “grounded in” or derived from data collected in the field. It takes phenomenology one step further by using participant perspectives, as well as other resources of information, about a common experience, process, or situation, to build an explanation that shows how something has occurred. The theory is generally not limited to a particular context.

For example, you might want to generate a theory that could explain how at-risk students show resilience—how they turn things around and become successful. You would interview students to learn about what experiences, events, and people the students thought were important to their success. The emerging ideas are tested or researched further through additional participant interviews. This is an iterative process of researchers generating new ideas, going back to the field and gathering more data to refine the original ideas.

The hope is to develop a theory that could provide causal explanations, not just a description, which could be used to address an issue.

Critical studies

Critical studies are distinguished by a researcher role as advocate to respond to themes and issues of marginalized individuals. These studies are focused on systems of power and control, privilege, inequity, dominance and influence based on race, gender, and socioeconomic class. Typically, theories of marginalize groups are used, such as critical race theory, queer theory, and feminist theory. For example, a researcher might focus on the inequitable treatment of students with learning disabilities, or students whose primary language is not English. Data would be gathered to challenge the status quo and to initiate action to ameliorate injustices.

The sixth and final major type of qualitative study is narrative inquiry.

The goal is to use individuals’ actual lived stories to provide a deep and rich understanding of a specific phenomenon.

Narrative inquiry is characterized by

• Stories organized in a logical sequence

• Use of several sources of data

• An emphasis on how stories relate to social culture

• Exploration of identity formation

• An emphasis on “turning points,” critical moments that provide meanings

• A collaborative relationship between the researcher and participant(s)

Narrative research depends heavily on the researchers’ skill in deciding what information to gather, how that information is analyzed, and what themes arise.

One example is to examine the phenomenon “collaborative curricular making” among middle school physical education teachers. The emphasis is on context, fluid design, and multiple sources of data.

This includes the introduction to the six main qualitative research designs. Next, we will learn various data collection methods for qualitative research.

There are five steps in collecting qualitative data:

1. Identify nature of data sources and data collection techniques

2. Enter the field, i.e., the site or sites, this is especially important for ethnographic studies or case studies because the sites will provide the best data for understanding the investigated phenomenon.

3. Identify specific data collection techniques using one or multiple methods, including interviewing, observation, and document analysis

4. Collect data

5. Analyze data

Please note how some steps loop back to inform changes in the design – this is the recursive aspect of data collection. What is collected depends, to some extent, on what has been found through previous data collection efforts.
There are three commonly used techniques for collecting data for qualitative research. They are interviewing, observation, and analysis of document and artifact.

Observation is characterized by observing naturally occurring behavior over many hours or days. Observer roles vary by the extent of involvement by the observer.

1. Participant observer is a passive observer without becoming part of the process in any way.

2. Observer participant is a moderate observer that is identified as a researcher but does not take the role of the participant.

3. Participant observer is an active observer that participates as a member of the group but is know as a researcher.

4. Complete participation is to be considered as a member of the group and is not know as a researcher.

We usually use field notes to collect observational data. They are usually recorded as brief notes during the observation. The field notes include detailed descriptions of what was observed and researcher’s interpretations of the scenario. They are considered the raw data that are analyzed to address research problems. The assumption is that nothing is considered trivial so whatever is seen, heard, or experienced is recorded. Observation sessions typically last 1 to 2 hours.

Field notes

• Include descriptive information.

• Use pictures, words, drawings, maps, and diagrams that capture objective details.

• Often include information about the researcher’s dress and actions.

• No predetermined categories or checklists

Field notes also include researcher’s subjective reflections, speculations, feelings, ideas, hunches, and impressions. They must be kept separately from the descriptive part of the field notes. Field notes must be accurate and extensive. They answer questions related to who, what, where, when, and how.

The second technique is about interviewing.

• It ranges from structured to unstructured formats.

• It is most are widely used method in qualitative studies.

• It provides rich details from participants’ perspective.

• It tends to be more economical than observations.

The steps taken to design qualitative interviews are illustrated here. The first step is to identify the purpose of the interview, What is the nature of the information you are trying to obtain?

The second step is to select the participants. This is based on making sure the interviewers can provide the needed information, as well as what is practical and feasible.

The third step is to identify the type of interview that will be conducted. It ranges from unstructured, semi-structured, to structured interview. In unstructured interview, the researcher begins with a general idea of what needs to be asked, but does not have a list of pre-formulated questions with precise wording. It’s usually done through informal conversational interview. With the semi-structured interview, topics and some possible questions are selected in advance, but the researcher decides the sequence and wording of the questions during the interview. Interviewers may use pre-established probes to facilitate the process. Probes are follow-up questions for the purposes of clarification or elaboration. For both individual and small group interviews, this is the most common approach.

The fourth step is select the protocol, e.g., a set of questions and prompts. Most typically, we ask five to ten questions, written on paper with space in between questions for note taking.

The fifth step is to select the setting in which the interview will take place. It is important to select a place to make the participant feel comfortable and allow researcher to record the conversation.

The final step is to pilot test with one or just a few individuals to make sure that the questions are clearly understood by the participants. The interview questions can be revised if necessary during the pilot testing stage.

Interviewing can be done individually or via a focus group.

For individual interviews

o Establishing trust and acceptance is critical.

o Be at ease and start with some informal conversation that is easy for the participant.

o Smile, relax, and reveal something about yourself if the opportunity presents itself.

o Listen carefully and note nonverbal indicators.

o Consider the willingness of the participant to talk when selecting interviewees.

For focus group interviews

o Typified by a one- to two-hour interview of 8 to 12 persons.

o Designed to promote interaction between individuals to lead to a rich understanding.

• Usually greater depth of understanding is achieved than with interviews.

o Discussion is guided by a moderator.

o Groups should be homogenous.

The third technique to collect data for qualitative research is through document and artifact analysis.

Documents are written records,

• e.g., Yearbooks, emails, websites, school budgets, dropout rates, committee minutes, memos, letters, newspapers, diaries, test scores, and books

• They are used to verify or support data obtained from interviews or observations.

To analyze and interpret document,

o A great deal of data is generated in qualitative studies that must be summarized and interpreted.

o Pages of field notes and interview transcripts must be examined and synthesized.

o The analysis is done both during and after the data collection phase.

o The goal is to discover patterns, ideas, insights, explanations, and understandings

Audiotapes, videos, documents, artifacts and researcher notes must be transcribed. Transcriptions should include both the respondent and researcher dialog. Some transcriptions include descriptions of what happens (e.g., prolonged silence).

Transcribed data are organized based on their sources:

• Emic data–information provided by the respondents

• Etic data–representations of the emic data by the researcher

The most common approach to organizing both emic and etic data is to read through the transcripts and to look for words, phrases, or events that seem to stand out, and then create codes for those words and phrases. Some may be major codes and under each major code, there are subcodees. For example, in a study to explore the opportunities and challenges of mobile learning in the K-12 classroom, opportunities and challenges are the two major codes. Under opportunities, there could be several subcodes (e.g., improved test scores, increased motivation, etc.) based on what the participants say about the advantages of mobile learning. We will follow he same coding pattern for the challenges.

At the end of the coding, themes/categories are created that capture the essence of the information.

There are software programs to facilitate this process.

The role of the researcher is different pending on the type of data colleting technique utilized. Here’s a table of examples when a researcher assume various roles through different data collection techniques. Pause your video to review the examples.

Here are a few procedures to enhance credibility of qualitative research data. For example, we can prolong the engagement with participants, ask them to read the transcript, triangulate the data from different sources, ask peer for feedback, seek external audit, and self-reflection on possible bias, and so on.

Pause your video for a few minutes to view them.

Here are some criteria for Evaluating Qualitative Research

• The researcher’s background and expectations should be clear.

• The conceptual and theoretical framework should be clear.

• The method for selecting the participants should be clear.

• Field notes should contain detailed, objective descriptions.

• Researchers should be trained to conduct data collection.

• Descriptions should be separate from interpretations.

• The researcher should employ multiple methods of data collection.

• The study should be long enough and credibility should be addressed.

In this video, we have learned different ways to conduct qualitative research and collect data via the following topics:

• Nature and characteristics of qualitative research

• Qualitative research validity

• Six main approaches

• Qualitative data collection methods, including

• Interviewing

• Observation

• Document analysis
